reviewText: Patricia Clarkson is luminous as Juliette and Alexander Siddig is just dashing. Despite the heat and the patriarchal society – the breathtaking cinematography makes me long to visit Cairo. The movie doesn’t shy away from the chaotic, unflattering aspects of the city but its scenes of beauty and grandeur are seductive. The love story is slow to simmer but well worth it. The last few scenes are stunning and heartbreaking.
summary: Egyptian Brief Encounter
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I thought this was a wonderful film. I especially enjoyed the leading man. The film is sensitive, interesting , with a nice ending.
summary: Cairo Time
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: This is an elegantly constructed romance with the finest nuances.  Most of us have experienced the romantic tension captured in this film, but few of us could portray it so beautifully.  I've always found Patricia Clarkson to be an accomplished actress, and she shines here in this superbly written and filmed romance.
summary: Divine and Beautiful Romance
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: It's rare that a good adult love story, like Cairo Time (2010), is rated PG. And yet I never missed any of the words or sexual content that would normally accompany such a film and give it a PG-13 or R rating. Just one casual F-word gives you a PG-13. But it wasn't "needed" in this movie. Cairo Time is an unbelievably fresh, yet classic film that surprised the hell...scratch that...heck out of me. Don't wanna tarnish that PG rating with my review. There's really not all that much I'm going to say about this film because I think its a simple film that's better to just watch and enjoy. There's nothing surprising here, no twists or turns in the plot, just a nice tale of the possibility of love between two people. The photography, sets, locations, and costumes are fantastic. Shot entirely on location in Cairo, Egypt, this film simply sparkles. The pyramids are incredible. And Patrician Clarkson and Alexander Siddig are simply spectacular in their acting. Classic! Or at least as I imagine "classic" to be. I wouldn't say that this is a great film that will reside in my library and be watched over and over throughout the years. But I wouldn't be surprised if I revisit it down the road. I give it 3 stars out of 5. And I give both actors 4 stars out of 5 for their performances. Without the two of them, and the subtle yet seductive chemistry between them, there would be no movie here. Enjoy!
summary: Classic, Subtle and Seductive. Gorgeously Photographed!
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: A beautifully photographed travelogue of modern day Egypt superimposed on a rather flimsy love story that lacks any semblance of interest or suspense.  As a result, this film is long and draggy.  The female lead is physically unattractive and a tad too old for her role.  The male lead is grizzled, sweaty and underweight.  Although it presents a few cultural insights, this movie is not a very good use of your time.
summary: As a Travelogue It's Fine
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Somehow the script, actors, and director have imbued the entire film with the sense of waiting, but filled it with so many inspiring, provoking, beautiful, intriguing moments, exchanges, and images.The light and landscape are gorgeous. Patricia Clarkson and Alexander Siddig create such subtle tension and intimacy, both in the actions they choose to take and choose to not take.Perfect costumes and environments transport the viewer somewhere else entirely, seamlessly.
summary: Wonderful, sumptuous waiting
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: This film has its strengths and its weaknesses. It is about a North American liberal woman who has come to Cairo Egypt to meet with her UN employed husband who is negotiation in Gaza. Unfortunately her husband is not able to break away from the conflict to join his wife and so she has been left alone. Thus to some extent the movie is about a woman traveling alone in an Islamic country and the cultural differences that both attract her and some which threaten her. Her husband's former employee, Tarek, now retired, is her companion while her husband is detained, opening many doors for her, including romance. The film also explores the concept that when we are in a different culture, feeling alone and isolated, and also feeling somewhat vulnerable, that our decisions and thoughts are not typical and we may act in a way that we would not under our normal circumstances.  The strength of having two characters over 50 years old is that sometimes more experienced people recognize these circumstances and are able to reconnect with former lives and attachments. The city of Cairo was beautiful and the film made me want to visit someday. The Nile River, which played a major visual role in the film, was stunning. There is a scene as to how Egyptian young men would respond to a blond North American woman walking the streets alone. They assumed they could seduce her and that she was sexually available, which highly threatened Juliette. But Juliette continues to explore. Sometimes this results in beauty and insight, especially the wonderful scene where she goes into an ancient mosque to see and hear the chanter's beautiful call to prayer. Sometimes her loneliness leads to problems, such as the scene where she tries to pass into Gaza and is turned back by the Israeli military border guards. The music throughout the film was very good, making me curious as to whether there is a soundtrack.Patricia Clarkson, playing the role of Juliette, is superb and as a great beauty now reaching age 50 she was perfect for the part. Alexander Siddig, playing Tarek, is also a good actor; sometimes however I felt he overplayed the role. There was something not quite right with his role; he seemed too physically close to Juliette too soon, which was a bit out of character.There were some weaknesses to the film. Tarek seemed a bit naive about Western North American culture which seemed out of character for a man who retired as an employee of the UN. The film was not a political statement, but a romantic statement about romance and vulnerability among those old enough to understand and reflect upon their feelings.
summary: Mature adults explore vulnerability and romance in an exotic city
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I first saw this film at the cinema.  The beauty of Cairo and its amazing landmarks impressed me enormously as did the gentle love story which grew as the film progressed.  A workaholic magazine writer arrives in Cairo to meet her husband who works in the Gaza Strip.  He is delayed and has arranged for an ex-workmate to meet his wife and get her settled.The husband`s delay gets longer and the friend goes to the aid of the wife, who cannot walk down a street without attracting attention and who goes unknowingly into a coffee shop which is for men only. He shows her Cairo, the bazaars, the unbelievable traffic both human and mechanical.  They take a boat trip on the Nile and sit on her hotel terrace, smoking apple steam from a giant pipe, They go to the wedding of his friend`s daughter and all the time their attraction to each other is growing.Watching this film again on DVD is again a lovely experience.  The dramatic scenery isn`t quite as grand as on the big screen, but it is still something to behold.  I really enjoyed this film, written and directed by a Egyptian Canadian.  She really has caught the feel and atmosphere of this ancient land.It is a beautiful film.  How sad that this magical country is at present going through such turmoil.  I hope that its problems may soon be sorted so that the people and tourists can return to their normal lives.
summary: A Beautiful Film
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Good movie with different perspective, interesting subject matter and terrific acting from credible performers.Cairo is a different kind of place and this film captures its beauty as well as the realities of life in that Egypt of the recent past.If the screenplay were written and shot today, it would be a different place with a new set of depressing realities.Good interview and short films included on the DVD.
summary: A pleasant find
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: "Cairo Time" is inept and inert, a criminal waste of talent and material. Alexander Siddig is handsome and charismatic as Tareq, an Egyptian café owner who shepherds a married American tourist, Juliette, (Patricia Clarkson) around Cairo. Patricia Clarkson is beautiful and wears her many dresses well.The film's publicity compares it to "Brief Encounter." Not a chance. There is no chemistry between Tareq and Juliette. This is the fault of Ruba Nadda's lifeless script and direction so inert you wonder if she has fallen asleep behind the camera and the actors are too polite to wake her.There are shots of the pyramids. There are scenes where characters stroll through an exotic bazaar, smoke hookahs, and dance at a wedding. There is a scene where men harass Juliette on the street. Juliette almost seems to like it; this takes on an ugly tone in the wake of the notorious Tahrir Square assault on Lara Logan. There is an entirely gratuitous scene that depicts Israelis in a negative way. Remarkable, because the film has no plot to speak of, but the director managed to work in her prejudices. These scenes ramble without reaching any point. There is zero dramatic tension. You don't wonder what's going to happen next - you pretty much know that *nothing* is going to happen next."Cairo Time" is an extraordinary waste of talent and material. Alexander Siddig is a charismatic star. I wish he had been given something, anything, to do. There is so much potential in the material. Say something about a potential romance between a Muslim man and an American woman. Say something about the potential of extramarital love. Say something at all! The film never does.
summary: Inept and Inert, a Waste of Talent and Material
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: It's a delicate romance that is handled very well.  In some ways you wish there was more but realize that what was given was plenty.  It's a movie I have seen over and over and will continue to see again and again.  The scenery is fantastic.
summary: Get tissues before watching
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: CAIRO TIME is a restrained, romantic movie about a long-married magazine editor, Juliette (Patricia Clarkson), who travels to Cairo to meet her husband, Mark (Tom McCamus), a U.N. worker.  Unfortunately, Mark is stuck in Gaza on U.N. business, so his charming former aide and friend, Tareq (Alexander Siddig), steps in to show Juliette the wonders of modern Egypt and keep her company.  Strong feelings develop between Juliette and Tareq, but of course, the consequences of acting upon them would be dire.  In this love story set in a strange, exotic land, the question for the audience is, "Will they, or won't they?"From David Lean's SUMMERTIME to Sofia Coppola's LOST IN TRANSLATION, stories of women in foreign places coming romantically and emotionally unhinged have made for some terrific films.  Unfortunately, CAIRO TIME's writer/director Ruba Nadda doesn't seem to have the chops to bring her characters and setting to life.Still, Nadda's top-notch cast does their best.  Patricia Clarkson is a wonderful, resourceful actress, who wrings the most out of whatever she's given to work with.  As her Egyptian paramour-at-a-distance, Alexander Siddig is tall, good-looking, gracious and self-confident.  Who wouldn't fall for him?The movie ambles at a leisurely, uneventful pace, rarely becoming truly engaging.  Rather than building character, finding the particulars that make the audience care about Juliette and Tareq, Nadda's lead couple are mere sketches.  Through their perfunctory dialogue, we learn certain facts about their lives, but we never get a strong sense of them as people with histories and attitudes, much less senses of humor.And while her own script lets her down, Nadda's flat direction doesn't help, giving her movie a languorous, monotonous feel.  In a story like this, you want the audience to believe that Juliette is overwhelmed with feelings of dislocation and upheaval.  The city of Cairo needs to become a living, breathing entity in the film.  Whether it's Lean's Venice or Coppola's Tokyo, it's accomplished with a directorial eye that Nadda doesn't seem to possess.  The filmmaking is flat and straight-ahead.  She provides some scenic looks at the pyramids, but we never get the feeling we're diving into an unfamiliar world.  Everything is a few steps removed.But CAIRO TIME is not necessarily wasted time.  If you like your relationships longingly forbidden, you might want to take the trip.
summary: A missed opportunity
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I had heard good things about this movie, and when I finally got around to watching it, I immediately wished I'd seen it earlier. I love this movie because it's so different from most other movies. For instance, rather than making the marriage between Juliette and Mark a troubled one, the filmmaker chose to make it stable and, from what we see, happy and fulfilling. There's no clear "bad guy" in this movie like there are in so many movies involving love triangles.The acting is also great, especially on the part of Siddig. I'd not seen him in anything since his Star Trek: Deep Space Nine days, and I was amazed. He has the character of Tareq down to every detail, including his walk. Tareq was one of the sexiest characters I'd seen on film in a very long time, but Siddig keeps that under control. Tareq is by far the more interesting of the two characters. He's extremely respectful of women, institutions, and societal expectations, which is a great asset, but can also be a liability. He is not, it seems, the type to really go after what he wants. Rather, he lets fate decide things.The Juliette character is a little flat; she doesn't seem to have nearly as much depth as Tareq, but Clarkson does a lovely job with her, especially in the ending scene in the cab. That scene was just perfect.The scenery is also beautiful, as is the music. And, I loved the little pieces of the movie that worked so well together, especially with respect to the wedding in Alexandria. Juliette's son has eloped, so she missed out on his wedding. Yasmeen's husband has died, so Tareq is, in a way, filling in for him. The scene on the roof during the wedding is my favorite in the whole movie.When the ending comes, you feel sad that you have to leave the world these characters inhabit, and it's clear that at least two of them are very sad to leave that world, too.
summary: Beautiful city, story, and music + great acting from Siddig
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: This is a nice movie but lacked the romantic punch that was necessary for it to be deemed a romantic movie. Tareeq did not seem remotely interested in `Miss Juliette'. One would have to possess amazing psychic powers to deduce that emotions were bubbling under the surface. One could also argue that as a friend/employee of Juliette's husband, he would not have `gone there' anyway but I doubt that would have prevented him from trying his luck, if he really wanted to. After all, as a Muslim he knows that no Muslim man worth his salt would ever in a million years leave his wife or any female family member in the hands of another man whether that man was married or not. He was gentlemanly but quite cold and distant, with very little smiling or even interest in selling his city to a strange American woman. You saw no build up in the way that `The bridges of Madison County' seduced the viewer.A few points that I found completely unbelievable:I have been to Cairo and much of it is squalid, noisy, dirty and rowdy, however the scenes looked like the Old City of Jerusalem. I hope the average viewer is not swayed in rushing to Cairo to experience this, I can assure you that the city is mega crazy.Juliette's ignorance in just hopping on a bus to Gaza had me raging. What is it with we Westerner's who believe that the world is our oyster just because we come from a `free' country ? I felt the same way after reading Down the Nile: Alone in a Fisherman's Skiff by Rosemary Mahoney.The se xual harassment that she experienced, at the beginning....well I can well believe this. I have been to Egypt and have seen and experienced this for myself. It is very bad indeed. In her defence, I didn't think that she was dressed untoward, just that she looked like a tourist. But what surprised me was that as an Egyptian man who generally tend to be either charming or creepy, Tareeq did not leave a contact number with her when he dropped her off at the hotel, it would have prevented her from braving the streets by herself or at the very least, the hotel staff would have encouraged her to use a taxi. This I did not find believable.Secondly, I am staggered that she did not notice that no women were at the cafe and sauntered in off the streets completely oblivious. This is a predominantly Muslim country where female genital mutilation is rife and there are very specific norms in terms of how a woman should behave and one just has to respect that, even tourists.Surprised that when she decided to visit the citadel, there wasn't a soul in sight and as such was able to walk into the building as the call was being made to prayer. For a Western woman, this would never happen in a million years.The dress that she wore to the wedding and later to visit the pyramids was beautiful but way too revealing for any woman to wear on the streets of Cairo whether she was in the company of a man or not. But like I say, gorgeous dress.Get the movie for the outstanding scenery, the pyramids lit up at night is beautiful. But if you are thinking of a similar performance from Patricia Clarkson like her performance in 'Vicki, Christina, Barcelona' then you may be disappointed.
summary: Breathtaking cinematography but the movie is a false representation of Cairo
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I felt deeply satisfied after watching " Cairo Time ", a different , tender love story between an american woman visiting the arab metropolis and an egyptian gentleman who used to work for her husband . Canadian/Syrian director Ruba Nadda allows her leads to get carried away by the breathtaking beauty of the city they wander but doesn't turn a blind eye to it's harsh realities : a visit to a carpet factory in which only underage children work , as picturesque as it might look at first glance , is a striking social comment .Above all though , what stays with the viewer is the discreet romance between her two charismatic leads . As Juliette , Patricia Clarkson brings a very quiet , introspective tone to the character and her very balanced measurement of feelings in the perfomance is truly remarkable . Nadda has said that she wrote the part of Tareq specifically for Alexander Siddig and her choice has payd off : his good manners ,honesty and noble spirit will make female viewers swoon and i was particularly impressed with his last scene at the hotel lounge which i found particularly moving . Overall , this is a rare gem of a film : modest and sensual , slow-paced and witty  . Highly recommended !
summary: Falling in love with the desert
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Patricia Clarkson shines in this single and poignant story that turns around the seek of his husband, kidnapped in Gaza. While she awaits for his freedom she will meet Tareq an very close friend of her husband, who will teach her these little unsaid delights of Egypt. Scented, touching and gratyfying movie.
summary: From Cairo with love!
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Sweet, romantic short film.  LOVED the music and scenery.Not a fast paced film.  Perfect if you're looking for a little romanceand tour of Egypt on a rainy afternoon.
summary: Romantic Trip to Egypt.
Title: Cairo Time

reviewerName: John G. Rodriguez "Puerto Rican Critic at Large"
reviewText: What a great low key film.  Patricia Clarkson is a greatly under-ratted actress.  Hollywood needs to use her more. Bravo!
summary: Things Just Happen
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I may be overstating my opinion that the only reason CAIRO TIME was filmed was to feature the city of Cairo in a film for western audiences, a rarely seen locale, but, in retrospect, that seems to me to be the only justification to view it.Here, Juliette Grant (Patricia Clarkson) arrives in the Egyptian capital to meet up with her husband Mark, a United Nations official, for a discovery tour of the city. But Mark is off swanning about Gaza on an aid mission and can't make it back in a timely manner, so Juliette is left to her own devices. She discovers that walking about Cairo on her own just won't do; she's constantly stared at and followed by strange men. The surprise is that she seems surprised by this. In any case, she falls into the company of Mark's good friend, Tareq (Alexander Siddig), who takes it upon himself to show her the sights and give her some sorely-needed clues about Arab culture.Clarkson can be luminous and has done some good stuff, e.g. roles inThe Green MileandThe Station Agent. But here, she's so ethereal as to be almost invisible. And Tareq, as her potential lover in an exotic place, is entirely too passive.Only at the end, in a scene involving Mark and Juliette in the back of a taxi, did I get a faint hint of the latter's repressed yearning that was so powerfully depicted by the Francesca Johnson character (Meryl Streep) in her husband's pick-up truck at the end ofThe Bridges of Madison County, perhaps my favorite chic-flick of all time. CAIRO TIME could've perhaps achieved the same overall intensity and excellence had it tried harder.But the views of Cairo were spectacular.
summary: A flimsy pretext for a Cairo travelogue
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Canadian director Ruba Nadda's "Cairo Time" is one of those slight wisps of a movie. It sets a quiet mood, and to enjoy the piece--it's best to just let it sort of flow over you. If you are expecting any real plotting, this gentle and picturesque travel document is probably NOT to your taste. However, if you're in the mood for a pleasantly involving mini-indie about unexpected connections amidst the pyramids--"Cairo Time" is sweetly appealing. Featuring the queen of independent cinema, Patricia Clarkson, Nadda has crafted a bittersweet portrait of middle-aged attraction. It is a film that never declares its intentions overtly but lets a real kinship between its principle characters develop naturally.Clarkson plays a diplomat's wife who arrives in Cairo to join her husband (who has been stationed there) for an extended vacation. When he can't break free from his obligations, Clarkson is left isolated in the foreign city. Adjusting to the unfamiliar culture, the new time zone, concern for her husband's safety, and the differences in sexual politics--Clarkson is a stranger in a strange land. Alexander Siddig, as a former colleague of Clarkson's spouse, is the only person she knows in the city and the two start to spend more time together. From initial awkwardness to increasing familiarity, the two form a real friendship in the beautiful land. But romantic stirrings exist as well, however chaste, and this is unexpected, unsettling and immensely pleasurable to Clarkson."Cairo Time" is probably most successful, however, as a travelogue. The attractions, sights, and city streets are shot in all their shimmering beauty. The film functions as much as a love letter to Cairo as a fully formed narrative. Clarkson is great, as always, and Siddig is a revelation! The two share a comfortable compatibility that make it easy to spend time with them. There are a few awkward moments, however, where Clarkson is gently accosted by huge groups of men that seem slightly overcooked--but in a film this understated, it's no wonder they stuck out. Charming, all in all, "Cairo Time" is a small film that should be enjoyed for its unapologetically subdued pace. KGHarris, 1/11.
summary: Gentle Flirtations In This Shimmering Travelogue Exploring Modern Egypt
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Don't think for one minute that this movie is one of those dumb romantic/chick flicks with Cairo thrown in for allure.  It is as deep and complex as Arabic coffee, expertly crafted and with a hint of bitterness.  (And yes, that actor is the guy who plays the doctor on "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine".)
summary: As deep and complex as Arabic coffee!
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: So I haven't reviewed a movie in a while because very rarely will a movie move me to actually review it.  I mean, I like movies but not as much as I like books.  However, this movie was just so beautifully done that I had to share about it.This is a Canadian independent film that was directed by Rubba Nadda and stars Patricia Clarkson and Alexander Siddig. Patricia Clarkson plays Juliette, a Canadian journalist who arrives in Cairo in order to vacation with her husband who is a UN official in Gaza.  Her husband has been delayed so he asks his friend, Tareq (played by Siddig) to be her guide and protector in Cairo until he can escape from his duties to vacation with her. Juliette finds herself falling in love with Cairo but also with Tareq, much to her surprise.Now, I've never been to Cairo, although I really want to go there someday but this movie made me believe that I had a really good feel for the city - its people, its traffic, its mosques and its coffee shops. And yes, even the pyramids, although I'm sure that it won't be the same as sitting there and feeling the dust or smelling the pyramids themselves. It's very elegant and masterfully done and the acting was absolutely beautiful to watch.  Highly recommended.
summary: Make Time for Cairo time
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I can see why some viewers came away with the perceptions they did, but if you watch and listen closely you understand the characters better.  Clarkson's character, Juliette,is a quiet woman who has held the fort for a husband involved in world affairs.  Her children are now grown, she and her husband are taking a long put off trip together, then he doesn't show.  She is quietly distraught and disoriented as she copes with worry, odd sleeping patterns  and the unfamiliar city.  But if you watch what is happening this is as much a story about a woman learning to know herself again, while she comes to know another person.Siddig's character is meeting a woman he has only known through a third party, her husband. As the story progresses we find he has shut himself off from love and romance. But when she comes to him for company he finds himslef talking about things he's not thought of in years.  As they spend time together they discover how much they are alike. Both quiet gentle people, who like to watch the world, take things in and can sit quietly without speaking. In the final events of the story she offers him what appears to be a small thing, but it is an enormous thing emotionally.  She gives over a memory she had planned with her husband to him, and in the end lies to keep it secret.  The secret is as deeply felt as if they had made love.The Director loved Cairo with the camera, and brought out the tender subtleties both of these actors possess. It's a delight to see a film about people in the Middle East just living side by side and going about their lives. This is for the patient and serious film lover.
summary: Quiet, Beautiful and poignant
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I loved every minute of this film and plan to see it again.  The movie is not only a wonderful portrait of Cairo and its people, it touches on the contrasts of US and Egyptian culture. There is a light romance, the kind you know can never be.First, there is the visual beauty of Cairo. In the print I saw the the color was not great, but this did not diminish the beauty of the city or the people. The street scenes, Tareq's coffee house, the Corniche, Khan el-Khalili, the Nile, Ramses Station, the traffic, the desert, the mosque, the wedding etc. were all true to my experience of Egypt.Then there is the beauty of the people. When Juliette asks why no one has asked her to leave the men only coffee house, Tareq says "It would be rude". When she says the men are following her his friend says "You are a beautiful woman."  This courtesy and easy grace characterized the Egyptian people I knew. The people in national dress from many parts of Africa, the many styles of hijab and galabaya reflected the diversity and spirit of Cairo. It reminds you that Egypt has been a melting pot since long before the US was even conceived.Then there was the contrast of culture. Julliette can not imagine possible dangers for her regarding the letter she has delivered. She is surprised at the reactions to her daughter's degree and her son's elopement. Tareq accepts that the girls in the carpet schools are saving for their weddings and Julliette sees exploitation. When Juliette's husband finally arrives he looks scruffy and overly casual compared to the immaculate and formal Tareq.My only criticism is about Juliette's wardrobe. The low necklines of the gown and the bathrobe don't fit the style of the film. Juliette was an intelligent woman. After a day in Cairo, why would she wear such a sheer skirt to a mosque?If you love Cairo and the Egyptian people, you will love especially love this movie.
summary: Beautiful Portrait of Cairo and its People
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: This movie felt like "L'Aventura" .  Each time I have seen that movie I feel such intensity of unspoken desires, tension, sadness...and disillusionment.  The characters yearn for a romantic ideal which the "object" will inevitably fail to fulfill.  Though in "Cairo Time" the characters do not consummate those fantasies, the viewer feels their intensity.  During each event of the film the impulse to overcome "rules" and its potential for disaster, slowly works its will. Those fantasies and stirred up needs appear likely to spill over into disillusionment with "normal life".  Often reviewers commented that the movie expresses a superficial-cleaned up view of Cairo or that the main characters were not politically correct or sophisticated "they should have known...".  Yet such superficial characters and glossy settings represent a protection against deep emotion. They are revealed as brittle when "fate" takes a hand.  A woman who has not been admired by young men for years may feel invisible to men and perfectly safe to wander the streets.  When young men follow and crowd her she is suddenly visible and vulnerable. Unfamiliar sensations change her perceptions of others.  When the husband suddenly appears, her emotional nature tries to regain that familiar surface but instead, suddenly she shows true pain.  To summarize-- I disagree with others who deny that this film is more than a lovely unreal travelogue.  I feel it contains many painful truths.
summary: Underlying sadness and tension
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Opinions range across the board on Ruba Nadda's "Cairo Time," and it's not a film for every taste. But for those who can appreciate the leisurely, insinuating grace of Nadda's direction and screenplay, it's an unforgettable gem. Patricia Clarkson is outstanding--giving one of the best performances of her career--as a woman at loose ends. A magazine writer and mother of grown children, she arrives in Cairo to meet her diplomat husband, only to find he is embroiled in delicate negotiations in Gaza. He has asked his close friend (Alexander Siddig), a coffee bar proprietor and retired UN official, to be her guide in his absence.Beautifully photographed by Luc Montpellier, "Cairo Time" begins as a film about culture shock, progresses as an earnest plea for the rights of women in Egypt and elsewhere, and ends as an almost-romance in which Clarkson and Siddig's characters develop a delicate, unexpressed but powerful mutual attraction. "Cairo Time" is reminiscent of several films, most notably "Lost in Translation" but also "Brief Encounter" and Francois Girard's "Silk." Some viewers--the ones who hated "Silk"--will find "Cairo Time" intolerably slow; others, however, will thrill to the exquisitely nuanced writing and performances. I loved it, and I think viewers with sufficient patience to savor a slowly unfolding story of personal discovery will love it, too.Extras on the DVD include a "Making Of" documentary; a Q&A; session with Nadda, Clarkson and Siddig at the Toronto Film Festival; and a selection of Nadda's early short films. The short films, while interesting, only emphasize what a quantum leap "Cairo Time" was for Nadda as a filmmaker.
summary: A delicate and moving film about an almost-romance.
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: "Cairo Time" seems to be inspired by the restraint of silver screen romances of the 1940s. "Casablanca" comes to mind for Ingrid Bergman's passionate but loyal and decorous character -and for the exoticism of that Moroccan city. "Cairo Time" is a romantic drama, however, without political intrigue or action. The action is in the characters' emotions, but they are rarely expressed overtly. Juliette Grant (Patricia Clarkson) is a magazine editor whose husband works for the United Nations in Gaza. She has traveled to Cairo to meet him for a romantic vacation, but he has been delayed due to unrest in Gaza. So Tareq (Alexander Siddig), an Egyptian former colleague, meets Juliette at the airport and gets her settled into her hotel.The city of Cairo is a big part of this film, with all of its chaos, beauty, poverty, ancient wonders and modern skyscrapers, both Western and Eastern, Muslim and secular.  Writer and director Ruba Nadda, an Arab Canadian, references the city's relaxed pace in the title "Cairo Time", and she has adopted that pace for the film. But it's not dull. The film is only 90 minutes long. It's just not frenzied, as that would be out of place in the extreme heat and languorous Mediterranean culture. Juliette is going stir crazy at the hotel with nothing to do but worry about her husband, so she sets out to explore. At first alone, but when it becomes clear that is a challenge for a blond woman in an Arab city, Tareq becomes her guide.The adventure catches Juliette when her role is changing. Her children have left home. She's come a long way to be closer to her husband, but, for the moment, those plans have fallen through. Tareq is a man who is very familiar with Western ways, having worked for the UN, but he has a traditionalist streak. Juliette and Tareq make a gracious and handsome pair. Though the focus is more on Juliette's inner life during this time, I like Alexander Siddig's performance a lot. I'm not used to seeing a lot of subtlety from him, but what Tareq would never say shows on his face and in his tone: his effort to balance his annoyance with Western self-righteousness, his attraction to his friend's wife, his essentially liberal nature, and the traditions that are his identity.The DVD (MPI 2010): Bonus features are a "Making of" documentary, a Q&A; session, 4 short films written and directed by Ruba Nadda, a theatrical trailer (2 min), 1 deleted scene (3 min), and an audio commentary. In the "Making of" documentary (7 min), Ruba Nadda talks about why she made the film, the cast, and filming in Cairo. "Toronto Q&A;" (26 min) is a September 2009 panel discussion with the director, Patricia Clarkson, and Alexander Siddig. The audio commentary is by writer/director Ruba Nadda and cinematographer Luc Montpellier. They talk about the 25-day shoot in Cairo, scene by scene, the challenges of different etiquette and regulations in Cairo, locations, themes, pacing. Subtitles for the film are available in English SDH and Spanish.
summary: Restrained Flirtation between Two Cultures Amid the Bustle and Beauty of Cairo.
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: In a rare leading role, Patricia Clarkson playes Juliette, a magazine editor from North America (never specific as I recall) who is married to a UN official assigned to Gaza.  The couple planned to meet in Cairo for a long vacation.  When Mark (Tom McCamus) is held up, he asks a former employee and friend to meet Juliette at the airport and see her to her hotel.Tareq (Alexander Siddig), a Syrian national has lived in the city for years and owns a coffee shop.  Adventuress Juliette decides to explore the city on her own, but finds it difficult due to the attraction she creates.  A blond Western woman alone in a bustling Muslim city gets noticed.  Eventually she calls upon Tareq to show her around.  Naturally there is an attraction.  Will they or won't they (PG rating will give you a clue)?Director and writer Ruba Nadda does a fine job of highlighting the ancient city, but alas the film is ponderously slow and deliberate.  Certainly Clarkson and Siddig are perfect in their roles.  Both are restrained, quiet and formal, perhaps to a fault.  Technically there is little to fault with the filmmakers.  I just wish the script was a bit livelier.
summary: 2 1/2 stars for well made but tedious story
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I was so pleasantly surprised after having read very mixed reviews of this film. It was just so lovely, no huge drama, just good acting and a solid story.  I am slightly obsessed with Egypt and felt transported to the bustling but fascinating Cairo.  I know not many people will see this, and it's a real shame because it is so unusual to find a film that is beautifully filmed and acted without resorting to exaggeration or unrealistic drama.  I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys relaxing with a good movie!
summary: Rare gem...
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Look I am a romantic and I love romantic movies. I appreciate what this movie tried to be but it fell short. This was one of the most boring, drawn out, long, slow, pointless movies I've seen in a very long time. I was excited to see it and was very disappointed that I had.A middle-aged woman (Patrica Clarkson) goes to Cairo to see her husband who works for the United Nations. While waiting on him to arrive she begins a friendship with her husband's friend (Alexander Siddig), a native who agrees to take her around while she waits on her husband. Simple enough. The problem is the film was so boring you'd rather be in surgery without anesthesia.It fell short as a romance because the characters didn't do anything interesting enough to show they had any chemistry. It was just like they were thrown together. I blame this on the slowness of the movie. I've seen movies where people ventured to foreign lands and took in the sights but the movies were still exciting. This movie was like watching a National Geographic special. At times I forgot I was watching a movie.Patricia Clarkson was droll and dead. She had no spark, no excitement, no nothing. Listening to her was like listening to someone who read a grocery list. She showed no emotion whatsoever. You couldn't tell if she were sad, angry, happy, turned on...nothing! She was like a lifeless paper doll. I've seen Clarkson in movies and she's been more livelier than this! Her boring acting is the main reason the movie moved so slow. The most exciting part was when the men followed her around and whispered nasty things into her ear. That's the ONLY time she had a hint of emotion or reaction to anything.The only reason I watched this movie until the end was because of Alexander Siddig. He was extremely handsome, alluring and intriguing. He kept you guessing through his laid back yet seductive attitude. At least he acted as though the film engaged him which is more than I can say for Clarkson.I'm sorry but it takes more than beautiful scenery and a gorgeous foreign land for a romance to be a real romance. If you took the Egypt element out of this movie you'd have a wooden stage play. The setting was the only thing that made this movie standout. It would've had no chance if it had taken place somewhere else. I also didn't like how we were teased with them getting together at the end only for the husband to come back! They could've at least shared a kiss.Another thing was that the movie kept throwing in unneeded characters and unnecessary subplots. This movie didn't feel like a movie let alone a romance.If you enjoy long, endless, pointless so-called romances between people with no chemistry or you just wanna see pretty buildings and beautiful landscapes, check this out. If you want a romance that's exciting and fulfilling with a lead actress who acts like she is at least interested in the movie, there are millions of films to watch instead of this.
summary: Like Watching Turtles Race
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I love this film!  besides the fabulous photography, the story and setting bring to life the reality of living in the Egyptian culture.  I would recommend it to everyone, but especially those who have never seen that fabulous part of the world.
summary: True to the culture and mores of Egypt.
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: In Short: A vacation planned for 2 is set on a new course when the husband is delayed. Tareq, a local, is tasked with helping Juliette around Cairo while her husband is away. As things go, an intimate bond is formed while Tareq accompanies Juliette on her time in Egypt.Stunning location. I couldn't write that enough. I am way to much of a pansy to ever go by myself so I admire Juliette's bravery as she explores a bit on her own. Her stumble into a men's cafe was light and humorous. She is a little quiet and reserved and I found that somewhat frustrating. Tareq was a wonderful character. I adored him. He was very gentle and respectful. Intriguing too."Cairo Time" is a clean and timeless romance. Nothing you couldn't watch with the kids at home. It is not wild abandon. It builds slowly and beautifully.  I rated it at 4 stars because though I enjoyed, I didn't love it and wouldn't rush out to buy it.
summary: A little romance on vacation in Cairo
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Had not seen this movie before purchasing it. It was an okay movie to watch once. I won't be viewing it in future.
summary: Watchable
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Not only is this a beautiful love story, you really feel for the characters.  Being shot in Cairo, it gives the audience a really nice perspective of this part of the world.  Good job on combining scenery, plot, and acting.
summary: Love the story, love the setting
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: I'd never heard of this but have a passing interest in Egypt so gave it a try. Despite the sometimes stilted dialogue and slower pace -- I enjoyed it for the most part. Beautiful scenery. Wish the lead actress wore more flattering clothes. Juliette's a lovely woman (I dont usually like blondes) but wore terribly clunky shoes. The male lead Tareq is a charming and complicated man.
summary: nice change of pace from Hollywood fare
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Cairo Time is slow-moving, thoughtful, non-traditional, gentle story of different levels of love and frienship between men and women. Never having been to Cairo myself, I found the scenery and cultural representations fascinating and moving. Patricia Clarkson's performance is wonderful, and Alexander Siddig's performance was captivating. Delightful film.
summary: Great study of characters and locale
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: While waiting for her husband in Cairo, a middle-aged Canadian magazine editor Juliette (Patricia Clarkson) unexpectedly finds a romance. Beautifully photographed on location in Cairo, Egypt, “Cairo Time” may remind us of films like “Brief Encounter” and “Summertime.” Ruba Nadda’s Canadian-Irish film may not be as great as David Lean classics, but is still impressive in its own way, thanks to the intelligent and nuanced performances from the star Patricia Clarkson.Clarkson’s heroine Juliette meets an Egyptian named Tareq (Alexander Siddig), a friend of Mark (Tom McCamus), her husband currently working for United Nations in Gaza. “Cairo Time” takes time – maybe too much time – showing what happens (and what doesn’t happen) to the lonely traveler.Juliette’s feelings are not explicitly articulated in words, but we sense what is going on between Juliette and Tareq because of the subtle performances from the lead, especially Patricia Clarkson.The filmmakers are lucky that they could actually shoot “Cairo Time” in Cairo. Authentic on-location shooting (that resulted in beautiful landscapes including Qasr al-Nil Bridge and the pyramids of Giza) would have been impossible after the Egyptian Revolution of 2011. But above all, they are very lucky that they could get Patricia Clarkson, whose great talent elevates the film a notch higher than it should be.
summary: Finding a Romance in Cairo: Patricia Clarkson Shines in "Cairo Time"
Title: Cairo Time

reviewText: Script is excellent and could have turned into an oscar winner if.......4/5Score:  good yet repetitive; the same arabic song go over and over in all coffee shops and cars, instead of choosing another 3/5costumes: Very badly chosen. too bad as they missed to add this additional charm to the movie 2/5Acting: very average and the choice of the arab actors was very poor. Both main Arab actors are not not even Egyptian and their Arabic sucks. The director should have found instead, the perfect matching actors for Patricia Clarkson in Egypt itself. 2/5. I love Alexander Siddig's other work, nothing against him personally.Overall it is a nice romantic movie that could have easily reached the oscars since the script is really good. Recommended for a relaxing romantic movie evening with Egypt in the background.
summary: Missed the train
Title: Cairo Time
